elements.content: The reaction of uranyl nitrate with cucurbit[6]uril (CB6) under hydrothermal conditions and in the presence of alkali metal ion nitrates has been investigated. Two complexes with Na+ have been obtained, [Na3(CB6)(H2O)8][(UO2)2(OH)2(NO3)4]·NO3·2H2O (1) and [Na1.5(CB6)(H2O)4][(UO2)6O2(OH)6(HCOO)3.5(H2O)]·8H2O (2), which differ by the presence in the latter of formate ions due to the hydrolysis of the dimethylformamide cosolvent. Both 1 and 2 display columnar, cationic Na+–CB6 complexes, with independent, anionic dinuclear (1) or one-dimensional polymeric (2) uranyl complexes. The molecular species [(UO2)3K3O1.5(OH)3(HCOO)3(CB6)3(H2O)6(DMF)3]·3H2O (3) is an original arrangement in which three K+ ions assemble three CB6 molecules around a trigonal axis and are themselves bound to the terminal oxo groups of a μ3-oxo-centered uranyl trinuclear unit. Only in the case of the cesium-containing complex [(UO2)2Cs2(OH)3(CB6)(H2O)4][(UO2)2Cs2(OH)3(NO3)2(CB6)(H2O)2][(UO2)2(OH)2(NO3)4]·2NO3·10H2O (4) is uranyl coordination to CB6 observed, resulting in the formation of columns with alternate CB6 molecules and [(UO2)2Cs2(OH)2]4+ heterotetranuclear units held by two μ3-hydroxo ions. 4,5-Dihydroxy-1,3-benzenedisulfonic acid (Tiron, H4tir) was used as an additional ligand so as to create bridges between the uranyl and alkali metal ions. Its disodium salt yielded the complexes [UO2Na3(Htir)(CB6)(H2O)11][UO2(Htir)(H2O)3]·NO3·11H2O (5) and [(UO2)2Na2(Htir)2(CB6)(H2O)8]·4H2O (6), obtained at room temperature and under hydrothermal conditions, respectively. Uranyl is chelated in both cases by one phenoxide and one sulfonate oxygen atoms. Whereas 5 is once more a columnar arrangement, with the uranyl complex units bound on either side, 6 is a two-dimensional assembly in which the uranyl ions are located on the outside of the sheets. Replacement of sodium by potassium ions gave the complex [(UO2)2K2(Htir)2(CB6)(H2O)8]·4H2O (7), in which, notwithstanding its closeness to 6, the different connectivity due to the larger size of potassium ions brings about the formation of a three-dimensional framework. These results show the considerable variety of architectures which can be generated in the uranyl–cucurbituril system, depending on the presence of additional cations and ligands, and also the potential of sulfonates in uranyl coordination chemistry.

elements.content: Depending on the alkali metal ion and the experimental conditions, various architectures, molecular or polymeric, can be obtained in the uranyl−alkali metal ion−cucurbit[6]uril system. Additional connectivity is provided by a disulfonated catechol used as an additional ligand, and two- and three-dimensional assemblies are thus generated.
elements.clean_text: Depending on the alkali metal ion and the experimental conditions, various architectures, molecular or polymeric, can be obtained in the uranyl-alkali metal ion-cucurbit[6]uril system. Additional connectivity is provided by a disulfonated catechol used as an additional ligand, and two- and three-dimensional assemblies are thus generated.

elements.content: Cucurbiturils are macrocycles that play an increasingly conspicuous role in coordination and supramolecular chemistry, with some particularly remarkable achievements having been reported, such as the synthesis of polyrotaxanes involving metal-containing threads. These molecules are efficient ligands for metal cations, with a strong affinity for alkali and alkaline-earth metal ions, and it is notable that the first crystal structure of a cucurbituril to be determined was that of the calcium ion complex of cucurbit[6]uril (CB6, Scheme ). Alkali metal cation complexation has been recognized as a way of increasing the solubility of CBs, which otherwise are only soluble in strongly acidic aqueous solutions. Since the first crystal structure determinations of sodium, potassium, rubidium, and cesium complexes of CB6, numerous other cases have been reported, as evidenced by a search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.32). The formation of one-dimensional, columnar or helicoidal coordination polymers is quite frequent among these complexes. Several reported complexes involve alkali metal ions in association with other metallic species such as d block cations and polyoxometalate anions, in which the alkali metal is often a link between the cucurbituril and the other metallic species. During an investigation of cucurbiturils as ligands for uranyl ions, several complexes of cucurbit[5]uril (CB5) with both alkali metal and uranyl ions have been isolated, the most remarkable species being heterometallic capsules with one cation complexed at each CB5 portal. A similar investigation has now been done with CB6, the results of which are presented herein. As a matter of course, the perfect match between CB5 and the uranyl ion, resulting in the latter being bound to all five carbonyl groups of one portal, is absent with CB6, which bounds uranyl through one or two carbonyl groups only. Nevertheless, the association of CB6 with uranyl and alkali metal ions, with the additional ligand 4,5-dihydroxy-1,3-benzenedisulfonic acid (Tiron) in some cases, permitted us to obtain novel heterometallic molecules or assemblies displaying original architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Cucurbiturils are macrocycles that play an increasingly conspicuous role in coordination and supramolecular chemistry, with some particularly remarkable achievements having been reported, such as the synthesis of polyrotaxanes involving metal-containing threads. These molecules are efficient ligands for metal cations, with a strong affinity for alkali and alkaline-earth metal ions, and it is notable that the first crystal structure of a cucurbituril to be determined was that of the calcium ion complex of cucurbit[6]uril (CB6, Scheme ). Alkali metal cation complexation has been recognized as a way of increasing the solubility of CBs, which otherwise are only soluble in strongly acidic aqueous solutions. Since the first crystal structure determinations of sodium, potassium, rubidium, and cesium complexes of CB6, numerous other cases have been reported, as evidenced by a search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.32). The formation of one-dimensional, columnar or helicoidal coordination polymers is quite frequent among these complexes. Several reported complexes involve alkali metal ions in association with other metallic species such as d block cations and polyoxometalate anions, in which the alkali metal is often a link between the cucurbituril and the other metallic species. During an investigation of cucurbiturils as ligands for uranyl ions, several complexes of cucurbit[5]uril (CB5) with both alkali metal and uranyl ions have been isolated, the most remarkable species being heterometallic capsules with one cation complexed at each CB5 portal. A similar investigation has now been done with CB6, the results of which are presented herein. As a matter of course, the perfect match between CB5 and the uranyl ion, resulting in the latter being bound to all five carbonyl groups of one portal, is absent with CB6, which bounds uranyl through one or two carbonyl groups only. Nevertheless, the association of CB6 with uranyl and alkali metal ions, with the additional ligand 4,5-dihydroxy-1,3-benzenedisulfonic acid (Tiron) in some cases, permitted us to obtain novel heterometallic molecules or assemblies displaying original architectures.

elements.content:
Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, NaNO3, and KNO3 were purchased from Prolabo, CsNO3 from Acros, and cucurbit[6]uril pentahydrate and the disodium salt of Tiron from Fluka.

[Na<sub>3</sub>(CB6)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>][(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]·NO<sub>3</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of NaNO3 (17 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared in low yield within three days.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O, NaNO3, and KNO3 were purchased from Prolabo, CsNO3 from Acros, and cucurbit[6]uril pentahydrate and the disodium salt of Tiron from Fluka.

[Na3(CB6)(H2O)8][(UO2)2(OH)2(NO3)4]⋅NO3⋅2H2O (1)

CB6⋅5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of NaNO3 (17 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared in low yield within three days.

Light yellow crystals of complex 2 appeared in low yield within two days.

elements.content: The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting “Paratone-N” oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to at least θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters were applied for some atoms in the disordered parts and/or solvent molecules. Some lattice water molecules were given 0.5 occupancy factors in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps, except for those of some water molecules, and the carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 (OH, OH2, CH, CH2) or 1.5 (CH3) times that of the parent atom. Some voids in the lattices of 1, 2, and 7 likely indicate the presence of other, unresolved water molecules. Special details are as follows:
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting "Paratone-N" oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to at least θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters were applied for some atoms in the disordered parts and/or solvent molecules. Some lattice water molecules were given 0.5 occupancy factors in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps, except for those of some water molecules, and the carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 (OH, OH2, CH, CH2) or 1.5 (CH3) times that of the parent atom. Some voids in the lattices of 1, 2, and 7 likely indicate the presence of other, unresolved water molecules. Special details are as follows:

elements.content: The sodium atoms are disordered over two sites with refined occupancies of about 0.8 (Na1, Na2) and 0.2 (Na3, Na4). Two of the aqua ligands (O11, O15) were found to be disordered over two sites and were given occupancy parameters in agreement with those of the corresponding sodium atoms. The uncoordinated nitrate ion is disordered over two positions related by a symmetry plane and sharing one oxygen atom. Some hydrogen atoms of the aqua ligands are compatible with the sodium ion main component only.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 1 

The sodium atoms are disordered over two sites with refined occupancies of about 0.8 (Na1, Na2) and 0.2 (Na3, Na4). Two of the aqua ligands (O11, O15) were found to be disordered over two sites and were given occupancy parameters in agreement with those of the corresponding sodium atoms. The uncoordinated nitrate ion is disordered over two positions related by a symmetry plane and sharing one oxygen atom. Some hydrogen atoms of the aqua ligands are compatible with the sodium ion main component only.

elements.content: The large displacement parameters of atoms Na2 and C4, together with the need for charge balance, led to giving these two atoms an occupancy parameter of 0.5, which corresponds in the latter case to a 50:50 disorder between a formate ion and two aqua ligands (O27, O28).
elements.clean_text:
Compound 2 

The large displacement parameters of atoms Na2 and C4, together with the need for charge balance, led to giving these two atoms an occupancy parameter of 0.5, which corresponds in the latter case to a 50:50 disorder between a formate ion and two aqua ligands (O27, O28).

elements.content: A very large void is located around (0, 0, 0.5) in which large Fourier-difference peaks are located. The species occupying this position is seemingly highly disordered, and it was impossible to resolve any atom, apart from three positions likely partially occupied by one uranium atom. The program SQUEEZE (PLATON) has been used to model this part of the structure. About 240 electrons have been found in the 560 Å3 void. A possibility is the presence of a neutral UO2(NO3)2(H2O)2 moiety, which corresponds to an electron count of 190, with additional surrounding water molecules. Considering the hypothetical nature of this part of the structure, this molecule was not introduced in the formula. Atom O10 was given an occupancy factor of 0.5 for charge equilibrium and to retain an acceptable displacement parameter.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 3 

A very large void is located around (0, 0, 0.5) in which large Fourier-difference peaks are located. The species occupying this position is seemingly highly disordered, and it was impossible to resolve any atom, apart from three positions likely partially occupied by one uranium atom. The program SQUEEZE (PLATON) has been used to model this part of the structure. About 240 electrons have been found in the 560 Å3 void. A possibility is the presence of a neutral UO2(NO3)2(H2O)2 moiety, which corresponds to an electron count of 190, with additional surrounding water molecules. Considering the hypothetical nature of this part of the structure, this molecule was not introduced in the formula. Atom O10 was given an occupancy factor of 0.5 for charge equilibrium and to retain an acceptable displacement parameter.

elements.content: The hydroxide atoms O34 and O35 are disordered over four symmetry-related positions each, and they have been given an occupancy parameter of 0.25 accordingly. The hydrogen atoms of these disordered hydroxides were not found. The highest residual electron density peak is located near atom U1.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 4 

The hydroxide atoms O34 and O35 are disordered over four symmetry-related positions each, and they have been given an occupancy parameter of 0.25 accordingly. The hydrogen atoms of these disordered hydroxides were not found. The highest residual electron density peak is located near atom U1.

<fn id="t2fn1">
<label>a</label>
<p>Symmetry codes: <bold>1</bold>: ′ = 1 – <italic toggle="yes">x</italic>, –<italic toggle="yes">y</italic>, –<italic toggle="yes">z</italic>; <bold>2</bold>: ′ = <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> – 1, <italic toggle="yes">y</italic>, <italic toggle="yes">z</italic>; <bold>3</bold>: ′ = 1 – <italic toggle="yes">y</italic>, <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> – <italic toggle="yes">y</italic>, <italic toggle="yes">z</italic>; <bold>4</bold>: ′ = 2 – <italic toggle="yes">x</italic>, 1 – <italic toggle="yes">y</italic>, 1 – <italic toggle="yes">z</italic>; ′′′ = 1 – <italic toggle="yes">x</italic>, 1 – <italic toggle="yes">y</italic>, –<italic toggle="yes">z</italic>; <sup>#</sup> = 1 – <italic toggle="yes">x</italic>, –<italic toggle="yes">y</italic>, –<italic toggle="yes">z</italic>; <bold>6</bold>: ′ = <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> + 1/2, 3/2 – <italic toggle="yes">y</italic>, <italic toggle="yes">z</italic> + 1/2; <bold>7</bold>: ′ = <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> – 1/2, 3/2 – <italic toggle="yes">y</italic>, <italic toggle="yes">z</italic> – 1/2.</p>

Symmetry codes: 1: # = x, y, z – 1; 2: # = –x, –y, 2 – z; 3: ′ = 1 – y, x – y, z; 4: ′ = 2 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z; ′′ = 1 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z; # = 1 – x, –y, –z; ∧ = 2 – x, –y, –z; 5: ′ = 2 – x, y – 1/2, 1/2 – z; 7: ′′ = x + 1/2, 3/2 – y, z + 1/2; ∼ = –x – 1/2, y + 1/2, –z – 1/2.

Only the main components of disordered sodium atoms are considered.

Six heterometallic compounds could be obtained under hydrothermal conditions in this study, either from CB6 and uranyl and alkali metal nitrates, with addition of DMF in the reaction mixture in some cases, or from CB6, uranyl nitrate, and the disodium salt of 4,5-dihydroxy-1,3-benzenedisulfonic acid (Tiron); another complex with the latter ligand was obtained at room temperature. Among the several additional ligands, particularly carboxylates, which were investigated so as to possibly provide links between the different components, only Tiron gave crystalline products under the conditions used; in particular, while several original compounds could be obtained from uranyl alkyldicarboxylates and CB6 with alkaline-earth metal ions, no such complex could be isolated with alkali metals under similar conditions. It is notable that the first compound comprising both uranyl ions and CB6 molecules, with no bonding of uranium to the carbonyl groups, was obtained in the presence of RbCl; rubidium ions are absent from the final compound in this case, which displays [(UO2)4O2Cl4(H2O)6] tetranuclear units built around two μ3-oxo ions and hydrogen bonded to CB6. This same complex was repeatedly obtained in the present study when alkali metal chlorides were used, and only nitrates provided novel complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Six heterometallic compounds could be obtained under hydrothermal conditions in this study, either from CB6 and uranyl and alkali metal nitrates, with addition of DMF in the reaction mixture in some cases, or from CB6, uranyl nitrate, and the disodium salt of 4,5-dihydroxy-1,3-benzenedisulfonic acid (Tiron); another complex with the latter ligand was obtained at room temperature. Among the several additional ligands, particularly carboxylates, which were investigated so as to possibly provide links between the different components, only Tiron gave crystalline products under the conditions used; in particular, while several original compounds could be obtained from uranyl alkyldicarboxylates and CB6 with alkaline-earth metal ions, no such complex could be isolated with alkali metals under similar conditions. It is notable that the first compound comprising both uranyl ions and CB6 molecules, with no bonding of uranium to the carbonyl groups, was obtained in the presence of RbCl; rubidium ions are absent from the final compound in this case, which displays [(UO2)4O2Cl4(H2O)6] tetranuclear units built around two μ3-oxo ions and hydrogen bonded to CB6. This same complex was repeatedly obtained in the present study when alkali metal chlorides were used, and only nitrates provided novel complexes.

elements.content: Two complexes were obtained from sodium nitrate, [Na3(CB6)(H2O)8][(UO2)2(OH)2(NO3)4]·NO3·2H2O (1) and [Na1.5(CB6)(H2O)4][(UO2)6O2(OH)6(HCOO)3.5(H2O)]·8H2O (2), the syntheses of which differ by DMF being added in the latter case. DMF undergoes hydrolysis to give formic acid and dimethylamine, as was often previously observed, not necessarily under hydrothermal conditions, but always in the presence of metal ions which are possibly catalysts for this reaction. The formation of dimethylammonium ions in situ has been shown to play a significant role in the formation and crystallization of CB6/dicarboxylate complexes with uranyl and alkaline-earth cations, and the present results show that, in the absence of other carboxylate ligands, formate anions will be bound to uranyl ions. Both compounds 1 and 2 comprise separate anionic uranyl-containing and cationic sodium–CB6 complexes. In compound 1 (Figure ), the single uranyl ion in the asymmetric unit forms the centrosymmetric, bis(μ2-hydroxo)-bridged dinuclear complex [(UO2)2(OH)2(NO3)4]2–, of which 10 other examples are given in the CSD. The average U–O(hydroxo) and U–O(nitrate) bond lengths, 2.303(4) and 2.557(16) Å, respectively, are unremarkable. The two crystallographically independent sodium ions (one of them located on a mirror plane) are disordered over two sites, with populations of 0.8 (Na1, Na2) and 0.2 (Na3, Na4) (see ). These positions and their images by symmetry are separated into two independent sets of three cations held by bridging water molecules and connecting two CB6 molecules, which differ by their orientation with respect to the latter. The two Na3 sets are related to one another by a pseudomirror plane parallel to the CB6 portal and the six sodium positions thus build a distorted trigonal prism. Since these two sets have identical geometries, only the main component will be discussed. Both Na1 and Na2 are in distorted octahedral environments, Na2 being located on the mirror plane which is also a symmetry element of the CB6 molecule. Both ions are bound to two carbonyl groups, with an average bond length of 2.344(13) Å. Sodium ions have previously been found to be bound to CB6 either through one or two carbonyl groups, with two cations being complexed at each portal, and with an overall average bond length of 2.42(15) Å, but this is the first instance of three sodium cations bridging two CB molecules. The two CB6 portals facing each other are parallel to one another and quite far apart, at about 5.3 Å, a distance smaller by about 0.8 Å than the height of the CB6 molecule itself (excluding van der Waals radii). The resulting columns are stacked so as to form layers in the bc plane, with a shift parallel to the c axis between adjacent columns in the layers as well as between layers, which brings the CB6 molecules of one column in contact with the inter-CB6 spaces of its neighbors along the a and b axes. The uranyl ion dimers and the nitrate counterions are located in the intercolumn spaces.

elements.content: In complex 2, the presence of formate ions originating from DMF hydrolysis results in the formation of the anionic, one-dimensional, ribbon-like coordination polymer [(UO2)6O2(OH)6(HCOO)3.5(H2O)]1.5– (Figure ). A very similar arrangement has previously been found in [HDABCO][(UO2)3O(OH)3(HCOO)2] (where DABCO is 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane), the main difference being the disorder present in 2, in which one formate ion is partially replaced by two aqua ligands (see ). In 2, as in the previous complex, μ3-oxo (O13, O17), μ3-hydroxo (O14, O15, O16, O18), and μ2-hydroxo (O19, O20) bridges coexist, with average U–O bond lengths of 2.22(2), 2.49(6), and 2.368(13) Å, respectively; these values are in agreement with those in the similar complex and in comparable structures in the CSD, as is the average U–O(formato) bond length of 2.40(2) Å. The trigonal geometry around the μ3-oxo ions is planar, with the sum of the adjacent U–O–U angles amounting to 359.9 and 360.0°, while the geometry around the μ3-hydroxo ions is much more distorted due the presence of the formato bridges on one side of the corresponding U3 triangles. The ribbons can be seen to be built from μ3-oxo-centered trinuclear subunits with the three uranium atoms in pentagonal bipyramidal environments, two of the polyhedra sharing one edge with the adjacent subunits. This is one more illustration of the propensity of the uranyl ion to generate quasi-planar one- or two-dimensional coordination polymers, owing to the structure-directing effect of its oxo groups which enforce an equatorial location for the other ligands. Two sodium atoms (one with half-occupancy) and two half-CB6 molecules are present in the asymmetric unit. The atom Na1 bridges adjacent CB6 molecules, while Na2 is bound to only one of them. Na1 and Na2 are both bound to two adjacent carbonyl groups of one CB6, Na1 being further bound to one carbonyl group from a second CB6 molecule. The overall average Na–O(carbonyl) bond length of 2.34(3) Å is identical to that in 1. Water molecules, terminal or bridging, complete the octahedral coordination sphere of the sodium ions. In contrast to the CB6 molecules being parallel in the columns in 1, they are strongly tilted in 2, with a dihedral angle of 63.50(12)° between the two O6 mean planes. These columns, running along the c axis, form sheets parallel to the ac plane, which are separated from one another by sheets of uranyl–organic ribbons directed along the a axis (Figure ). The previous investigation of the complexes formed by uranyl ions with aliphatic dicarboxylates in the presence of CB6 has shown that such packings of sheets formed by uranyl–organic species on the one hand and CB6 molecules or their alkaline-earth metal ion complexes on the other were quite frequent, evidencing a striking affinity between these planar components (not always truly two-dimensional, as here).

elements.content: The complex obtained in the presence of potassium nitrate and DMF, [(UO2)3K3O1.5(OH)3(HCOO)3(CB6)3(H2O)6(DMF)3]·3H2O (3), is the only one in this series to be a molecular neutral species. Although large voids are present in the packing, indicating the presence of other neutral components seemingly too disordered to be resolved (see ), this complex is worth describing for its very original geometry. The asymmetric unit contains one uranyl and one potassium ions, one CB6 molecule and additional oxo, hydroxo, formato, aqua and DMF ligands, and the whole molecule contains three such units assembled around a 3-fold rotation axis (Figure ). The three uranyl ions are bound to one central μ3-oxo ion (sum of the three U–O5–U angles 353.8°) and to three μ2-hydroxo ions [average bond length 2.39(3) Å]. One monodentate formate ion and one aqua ligand complete the uranium coordination sphere, which is pentagonal bipyramidal. An intramolecular hydrogen bond is formed between the aqua and formato ligands [O7···O4 2.696(7) Å, O7–H···O4 148.7°]. The bond lengths and angles around the uranium atom are unexceptional. The potassium ion is bound to three carbonyl oxygen atoms from the CB6 molecule, and to another, bridging one from a second CB6 molecule, with an average K–O bond length of 2.73(12) Å for the three bonds with the same CB6 molecule, or 2.82(18) Å for all bonds. Potassium complexes with CB6 are scarcer than those with CB5, and the average K–O bond length for those reported in the CSD (with bi- or tridentate CB6) is 2.79(13) Å, in agreement with the value in 3. Another potassium coordination site is occupied by an uranyl oxo group, with a K–O(oxo) bond length of 2.783(4) Å. Uranyl oxo groups possess a Lewis base character and they are quite frequently involved in bonding to a second metal ion (or even two metal ions), with the latter being either another actinide, or a lanthanide, d-block metal, alkaline-earth or, as in the present case, alkali metal ion. In particular, potassium ions are bound to two uranyl oxo groups in the complex with CB5. The average K–O(oxo) bond length for previously reported structures involving UVI (several such structures contain UV) is 2.78(9) Å, which perfectly matches the present value. The two trinuclear sets in 3 are thus connected by three strongly asymmetrical oxo bridges and they are rotated with respect to one another by 32.89(4)° along the trigonal axis. The coordination sphere of potassium is completed by one μ3-oxo ion (O10), possibly half-occupied (see ), one aqua and one DMF ligand, the latter being included in the CB6 cavity, giving an overall eight-coordinated environment of very irregular geometry. The large trimeric molecule is thus somewhat trigonal pyramidal in shape, the largest side being about 21 Å in length, with the connected set of three uranyl ions on top, which holds the three K(CB6) moieties, the latter being also bound to one another by bridging carbonyl groups, and tilted by 61.93(4)° from the U3 plane. The packing displays large cylindrical channels directed along the c axis, with an approximate diameter of 9 Å, which contain the disordered and unresolved additional species.

elements.content: The complex obtained with cesium ions, [(UO2)2Cs2(OH)3(CB6)(H2O)4][(UO2)2Cs2(OH)3(NO3)2(CB6)(H2O)2][(UO2)2(OH)2(NO3)4]·2NO3·10H2O (4), comprises three different complex units, which all possess an inversion center. One of them is the dianionic uranyl nitrate dimer with two μ2-hydroxo bridges which has been encountered in compound 1 and will not be further described. The other two are heterometallic complexes of CB6 which differ only by one of the ligands of uranyl, and as a consequence by their charge. In both molecules, one cesium ion occupies the center of each portal and is bound to all six carbonyl groups (Figure ). The Cs–O(carbonyl) bond lengths vary in a wide range [3.060(6)–3.635(6) Å, average 3.37(23) Å], thus indicating that the cation is somewhat too small to perfectly fit in the cavity, although it is displaced by only 0.05 Å from the mean portal plane. Only four cesium complexes with CBs are known: two of them involve CB5, which is bound through all five carbonyl groups to one cation much displaced from the portal, while the others are CB6 complexes with the cation either bound to six or to only four carbonyl groups; the average bond length in the only case similar to the present is 3.45(18) Å. A closed capsule is thus formed, which encloses a disordered hydroxide ion bound to both cesium cations. The nine-coordinate cesium ion is also bound to one terminal aqua ligand and one hydroxide ion (O13 and O22), with the latter bridging the cesium and uranyl ions. The uranyl ion is located on one side of CB6 and bound to one carbonyl group, with an average bond length of 2.448(8) Å in the usual range for such bonds [2.337(6)–2.545(6) Å, average 2.40(5) Å]. The uranium atoms in both molecules are assembled in dimers bridged by two hydroxide ions, which connect adjacent CB6 molecules along the a axis. The CB6 molecules are thus connected through heterotetranuclear [(UO2)2Cs2(OH)2]4+ units held by two μ3-hydroxo ions. Atom U1 in the tricationic complex [(UO2)2Cs2(OH)3(CB6)(H2O)4]3+ is further bound to two terminal aqua ligands, being thus in the usual pentagonal bipyramidal environment, while U2 in the monocationic [(UO2)2Cs2(OH)3(NO3)2(CB6)(H2O)2]+ moiety is bound to one aqua ligand and one nitrate ion. However, the latter is in a plane parallel to the uranyl axis, and not in the equatorial plane as usual. The latter contains the nitrogen atom, while the two coordinated oxygen atoms are displaced by 1.01 and 1.06 Å from it. Some examples of such a geometry have recently been reported, and an arrangement similar to that in 4 has been found in a uranyl ion complex with CB7. The U–O(nitrate) bond lengths are very long, with an average value of 2.766(3) Å, but the bonding is more symmetrical than in all the previous cases. The uranium environment geometry can best be viewed as pentagonal bipyramidal with a split equatorial vertex, as it has been described in neptunyl compounds. The columns of Cs2CB6 capsules bridged by uranyl groups are closely packed to form planes parallel to (0 1 1), in which the bumps of one column fit with the hollows of its neighbors, due to a shift by about one-half the unit cell parameter along the a axis between the columns corresponding to the molecules containing U1 and U2 (Figure ). The [(UO2)2(OH)2(NO3)4]2– dimers are located between the layers, as well as the nitrate counterions and the water molecules of solvation. An intricate network of hydrogen bonds link the different species present.
elements.clean_text: The complex obtained with cesium ions, [(UO2)2Cs2(OH)3(CB6)(H2O)4][(UO2)2Cs2(OH)3(NO3)2(CB6)(H2O)2][(UO2)2(OH)2(NO3)4]⋅2NO3⋅10H2O (4), comprises three different complex units, which all possess an inversion center. One of them is the dianionic uranyl nitrate dimer with two μ2-hydroxo bridges which has been encountered in compound 1 and will not be further described. The other two are heterometallic complexes of CB6 which differ only by one of the ligands of uranyl, and as a consequence by their charge. In both molecules, one cesium ion occupies the center of each portal and is bound to all six carbonyl groups (Figure ). The Cs-O(carbonyl) bond lengths vary in a wide range [3.060(6)-3.635(6) Å, average 3.37(23) Å], thus indicating that the cation is somewhat too small to perfectly fit in the cavity, although it is displaced by only 0.05 Å from the mean portal plane. Only four cesium complexes with CBs are known: two of them involve CB5, which is bound through all five carbonyl groups to one cation much displaced from the portal, while the others are CB6 complexes with the cation either bound to six or to only four carbonyl groups; the average bond length in the only case similar to the present is 3.45(18) Å. A closed capsule is thus formed, which encloses a disordered hydroxide ion bound to both cesium cations. The nine-coordinate cesium ion is also bound to one terminal aqua ligand and one hydroxide ion (O13 and O22), with the latter bridging the cesium and uranyl ions. The uranyl ion is located on one side of CB6 and bound to one carbonyl group, with an average bond length of 2.448(8) Å in the usual range for such bonds [2.337(6)-2.545(6) Å, average 2.40(5) Å]. The uranium atoms in both molecules are assembled in dimers bridged by two hydroxide ions, which connect adjacent CB6 molecules along the a axis. The CB6 molecules are thus connected through heterotetranuclear [(UO2)2Cs2(OH)2]4+ units held by two μ3-hydroxo ions. The uranium environment geometry can best be viewed as pentagonal bipyramidal with a split equatorial vertex, as it has been described in neptunyl compounds. elements.content: Only in complex 4 is the CB6 molecule coordinated to both the uranyl and alkali metal ions, while these ions are in different complex species with Na+ in 1 and 2, and K+ serves as a bridge between CB6 and uranyl in 3. Additional ligands permitting the bridging of sodium and uranyl ions to give a single framework species including CB6 were investigated, in particular in the family of polycarboxylic acids. However, the only ligand which provided interesting results, if not exactly those which were intended, is the sulfonated catechol 4,5-dihydroxy-1,3-benzenedisulfonic acid (Tiron); it was expected that this molecule could be partially included, through one sulfonate group, in the CB6 cavity, but this was not observed. Few crystal structures of complexes with this ligand are reported in the CSD, which involve alkali, alkaline-earth, d-block, or lanthanide metal ions. The two complexes [UO2Na3(Htir)(CB6)(H2O)11][UO2(Htir)(H2O)3]·NO3·11H2O (5) and [(UO2)2Na2(Htir)2(CB6)(H2O)8]·4H2O (6) have been obtained from reaction of the disodium salt of Tiron with uranyl nitrate and CB6, either in water at room temperature (5) or under hydrothermal conditions (6), while an excess of potassium nitrate gave the complex [(UO2)2K2(Htir)2(CB6)(H2O)8]·4H2O (7). The compounds 5 and 6 thus provide a novel example permitting to compare these two methods of synthesis, all other parameters being equal. In all these complexes, the uranyl ion is chelated by a phenoxide and a sulfonate oxygen atoms from Htir3–; it is notable that the deprotonated phenolic group is always the one permitting uranyl chelation with one oxygen atom of the sulfonate group in the ortho position. In both complexes 5 and 6, Na+ is only bound to one sulfonate oxygen atom, and to the CB6 molecule. It is notable that, in the trisodium salt of Htir3–, the cations are bound to phenol, phenoxide, and sulfonate oxygen atoms, which indicates that a rearrangement occurred, leading to the phenoxide group being bound to uranyl and to an overall decrease in the number of coordinated atoms. In 5, the asymmetric unit comprises three sodium ions bound to CB6 and to bridging or terminal aqua ligands, with only one of them bound to a sulfonate group (Figure ); the coordination environment geometry is distorted octahedral in all cases. Na2 and Na3 are each bound to two adjacent carbonyl groups from the same CB6 molecule, while Na1 is bound to two carbonyl groups pertaining to two different molecules, a columnar arrangement parallel to the b axis being thus built. The average Na–O(carbonyl) bond length, 2.38(7) Å, is in agreement with that measured in 1 and 2, and the Na1–O(sulfonate) bond length of 2.417(3) Å matches the average value of 2.43(15) Å for such bonds in structures reported in the CSD. [UO2(Htir)(H2O)3]− complex moieties are bound alternately on each side of the columns, and others are present as isolated counterions occupying the positions left free by the former alongside the columns (Figure ). In both these complexes, the uranyl ion is bound to one phenoxide and one sulfonate oxygen atoms and to three water molecules, while the second phenolic group retains its proton. The U1–O5 bond length of 2.264(3) Å in 5 is smaller than that of 2.44(3) Å measured in the only uranyl complex with a chelating catecholate, but it is typical of values measured for U–O(phenoxide) bond lengths [average from the CSD: 2.26(5) Å] (catecholate moieties are often part of Schiff base ligands, but the two bond lengths in the chelating mode are quite different due to geometric constraints or the presence of an additional metal atom; in the monodentate mode, they are close to that measured here). The U–O(sulfonate) bond length of 2.450(3) Å is slightly larger than the average value from the CSD, 2.38(2) Å. The packing displays an hexagonal array of uranyl ion complexes surrounding the columns, with an intricate hydrogen bonding network associating the complexes, counterions, and solvent molecules.

elements.content: Compound 6 is a very different species, in which the columnar arrangement of sodium ions bound to CB6 molecules is disrupted by the uranyl complex with Htir3–. The asymmetric unit comprises half a CB6 molecule, one uranyl and one sodium ions, one Htir3– anion and water molecules, coordinated or free. The bonding of uranyl to Htir3– is identical to that in 5, with however a U–O(sulfonate) bond length closer to the usual value. One of the aqua ligands is replaced by a sulfonato group from a second molecule, this group being bridging the uranium and sodium atoms through two of its oxygen atoms (Figure ). The sodium atom is bound to one sulfonate group, with a bond length slightly smaller than in 5, to two adjacent carbonyl groups [average bond length 3.35(4) Å] and to two water molecules, the five-coordinate environment being distorted trigonal bipyramidal, with O9, O13, and O20 defining the basal plane and O15 and O19 the apexes [O15–Na–O19 177.48(10)°]. This bonding scheme results in the formation of a two-dimensional assembly parallel to the (1 0 1̅) plane (Figure ), for which the total point symbol determined with the TOPOS software is (163)2(16)5, the first symbol corresponding to the two Htir3– anions and the second to the two UO2 2+ and two Na+ cations, and the CB6 molecule. As evidenced in the simplified representation of Figure , this assembly can be viewed as a tessellation of 16-membered rings when projected onto the bc plane, but it is very strongly corrugated and presents a sawtoothed profile when viewed down the [1 0 1] axis. With three cations bound to them, the Htir3– anions are the most efficient assembling species in this structure, but it is notable that one phenolic and three sulfonate oxygen atoms are uncoordinated, the full potential of the molecule being thus not reached, while several water molecules occupy coordination sites on both cations and do not contribute to further bridging. This is not unexpected however since sulfonates are rather weak ligands. The ligand Htir3– behaves identically in 5 and 6, apart from one more coordination bond with a sulfonate oxygen atom in the latter. This supplementary bond plays of course an important role since it results in the ligand bridging uranyl ions. However, the main structural difference arises from the disruption of the [Na3CB6] columns present in 5 and their replacement by isolated [Na2CB6] moieties which link the [(UO2)(Htir)] chains. The dimensionality is thus increased and the neutral polymeric assembly in 6 includes all the species present. A large decrease in water content (both for coordinated and free water molecules) is obvious in the structure obtained at high temperature, which is in line with the results of previous studies. A thorough investigation of complexes obtained at different temperatures led to the conclusion that this decrease in water content was entropy-driven and indicative of thermodynamic control.

elements.content: Sodium is replaced by potassium in complex 7, which is formed under hydrothermal conditions when potassium nitrate is added in excess to the reaction mixture leading to complex 6 (attempts at substituting sodium by lithium ions only gave complexes with partial replacement and quite intractable Na/Li disorder, while replacement by cesium ions gave a complex in which this cation is disordered over two positions, but could not be satisfactorily modeled). The two complexes 6 and 7 can be considered to be isomorphous, but the larger size of potassium brings about a different connectivity and, as a consequence, increases the dimensionality of the assembly formed. The uranyl-containing part of complex 7 is identical to that in 6, and it will not be further described. The potassium ion is located as its sodium counterpart, and it is also bound to two adjacent carbonyl oxygen atoms, with an average bond length of 2.70(7) Å comparable to that in complex 3 (Figure ). It is also bound to one sulfonate oxygen atom and two terminal aqua ligands, and three other oxygen atoms, although at larger distances, complete its coordination sphere. These atoms are the uranyl oxo atom O1, the phenoxide atom O3, and O12 from an aqua ligand; all three are bridging the uranium and potassium ions. At 3.151(2) Å, the K–O(oxo) bond length is larger than the usual average value of 2.78(9) Å, but these bond lengths have been found to vary in the 2.7–3.2 Å range. The other two bonds are also in the upper parts of the usual ranges and thus lie in the twilight zone in which consideration as true bonding is quite uncertain. However, these extra bonds give an eight-coordinate environment usual for potassium ions, with a quite irregular geometry. As a result of this increased connectivity, each Htir3– ligand is bound to two uranium and two potassium ions (one sodium only in 6); nonetheless, this does not add to the network formed since the cations linked through O1 and O3 are also connected by the sulfonate group, as in 6. The main difference comes from the bridging water molecule which connects the layers present in 6 so as to form a three-dimensional framework (Figures and ). The assembly is very intricate since the two-dimensional subunits are partially interdigitated and the new bonds are in fact nearly parallel to the sheets. Such an increase in dimensionality arising from a change in alkali metal cation connectivity in otherwise isomorphous structures has already been encountered, for example in the Rb+ and Cs+ complexes with bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid, or in the heterometallic complexes of uranyl and either K+ or Rb+ with pyrazinetetracarboxylic acid, with the larger cation giving a three-dimensional framework in both cases.

elements.content: The crystal structures in a series of complexes of CB6 with both uranyl and alkali metal cations have been determined, an analogous study having previously been done with CB5, while these ions have only been investigated independently of one another with CB6 up to now. Complexes could be obtained with Na+, K+, and Cs+. Unfortunately, no crystal could be grown with Li+, for which only one complex with CB5 has been reported, and none with CB6. In a general way, the uranyl ion displays a strong tendency to form planar or corrugated one- or two-dimensional assemblies, due to the two oxo atoms enforcing an equatorial positioning of the other ligands. Alkali metal cations have been used to increase the dimensionality of these assemblies through the creation of additional bridges involving the ligands or the uranyl oxo groups. However, this approach is not quite successful with the uranyl–CB6 system since, in the complexes formed, this ligand is more often bound to the alkali metal than to the uranyl cation. Indeed, in the two complexes with sodium cations, the latter are complexed by CB6 to form columnar one-dimensional polymers, while uranyl ions form either molecular dinuclear or one-dimensional ribbon-like species alongside. The complex with potassium ions appears as an oddity since it is the only one not to be polymeric: three CB6 molecules are assembled around a trigonal symmetry axis by three bridging potassium cations, the whole being bound to an oxo-centered uranyl trinuclear moiety by three bonds between the alkali metal and uranyl oxo groups, resulting in a large, neutral, trigonal molecule of unprecedented geometry. Cesium ions are complexed at each CB6 portal to form a closed capsule and in this only case uranyl ions are also bound to CB6. Bridging water and hydroxide ligands ensure the formation of a one-dimensional, columnar polymer. It was then attempted to introduce additional ligands which would bridge the two cations, and interesting complexes resulted from the use of the disodium salt of the sulfonated catechol Tiron. Two complexes including Na+ ions were obtained either at room temperature or under hydrothermal conditions: the former comprises one-dimensional Na–CB6 columns with uranyl–Tiron complexes attached on their sides through one sulfonate group, while the latter is a two-dimensional polymer in which Tiron bridges uranyl ions and Na–CB6 complexes. This increase in dimensionality for compounds grown at higher temperature follows the usual trend. Replacement of sodium by potassium ions gives a complex isomorphous to the last one, but the larger size of the cation leads to changes in the connectivity and a three-dimensional framework is built. It appears once more that a considerable variety of architectures can be generated in the uranyl–cucurbituril system, depending on the presence of additional cations and ligands. It is also notable that several of the compounds described herein display bonding between the alkali metal ion and a uranyl oxo group: these bonds, which are relatively common, provide an interesting strategy for possibly increasing the connectivity and dimensionality in uranyl–organic coordination polymers, in a direction transverse to the uranyl equatorial plane. The complexes with Tiron are novel examples of uranyl bonding by sulfonates, these being rather scarce at present, with only 17 structures reported in the CSD, most of them comprising the common, weakly coordinating trifluoromethanesulfonate anion. Although less efficient as ligands than phosphonates, sulfonates thus appear to deserve further investigation as ligands suitable for uranyl–organic framework synthesis.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The crystal structures in a series of complexes of CB6 with both uranyl and alkali metal cations have been determined, an analogous study having previously been done with CB5, while these ions have only been investigated independently of one another with CB6 up to now. Complexes could be obtained with Na+, K+, and Cs+. Unfortunately, no crystal could be grown with Li+, for which only one complex with CB5 has been reported, and none with CB6. In a general way, the uranyl ion displays a strong tendency to form planar or corrugated one- or two-dimensional assemblies, due to the two oxo atoms enforcing an equatorial positioning of the other ligands. Alkali metal cations have been used to increase the dimensionality of these assemblies through the creation of additional bridges involving the ligands or the uranyl oxo groups. However, this approach is not quite successful with the uranyl-CB6 system since, in the complexes formed, this ligand is more often bound to the alkali metal than to the uranyl cation. Indeed, in the two complexes with sodium cations, the latter are complexed by CB6 to form columnar one-dimensional polymers, while uranyl ions form either molecular dinuclear or one-dimensional ribbon-like species alongside. The complex with potassium ions appears as an oddity since it is the only one not to be polymeric: three CB6 molecules are assembled around a trigonal symmetry axis by three bridging potassium cations, the whole being bound to an oxo-centered uranyl trinuclear moiety by three bonds between the alkali metal and uranyl oxo groups, resulting in a large, neutral, trigonal molecule of unprecedented geometry. Cesium ions are complexed at each CB6 portal to form a closed capsule and in this only case uranyl ions are also bound to CB6. Bridging water and hydroxide ligands ensure the formation of a one-dimensional, columnar polymer. It was then attempted to introduce additional ligands which would bridge the two cations, and interesting complexes resulted from the use of the disodium salt of the sulfonated catechol Tiron. Two complexes including Na+ ions were obtained either at room temperature or under hydrothermal conditions: the former comprises one-dimensional Na-CB6 columns with uranyl-Tiron complexes attached on their sides through one sulfonate group, while the latter is a two-dimensional polymer in which Tiron bridges uranyl ions and Na-CB6 complexes. This increase in dimensionality for compounds grown at higher temperature follows the usual trend. Replacement of sodium by potassium ions gives a complex isomorphous to the last one, but the larger size of the cation leads to changes in the connectivity and a three-dimensional framework is built. It appears once more that a considerable variety of architectures can be generated in the uranyl-cucurbituril system, depending on the presence of additional cations and ligands. It is also notable that several of the compounds described herein display bonding between the alkali metal ion and a uranyl oxo group: these bonds, which are relatively common, provide an interesting strategy for possibly increasing the connectivity and dimensionality in uranyl-organic coordination polymers, in a direction transverse to the uranyl equatorial plane. The complexes with Tiron are novel examples of uranyl bonding by sulfonates, these being rather scarce at present, with only 17 structures reported in the CSD, most of them comprising the common, weakly coordinating trifluoromethanesulfonate anion. Although less efficient as ligands than phosphonates, sulfonates thus appear to deserve further investigation as ligands suitable for uranyl-organic framework synthesis.

Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, NaNO3, and KNO3 were purchased from Prolabo, CsNO3 from Acros, and cucurbit[6]uril pentahydrate and the disodium salt of Tiron from Fluka.

[Na<sub>3</sub>(CB6)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>][(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]·NO<sub>3</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of NaNO3 (17 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared in low yield within three days.

[Na<sub>1.5</sub>(CB6)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>][(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>6</sub>O<sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>6</sub>(HCOO)<sub>3.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]·8H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of NaNO3 (17 mg, 0.20 mmol), DMF (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (3 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 2 appeared in low yield within two days.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>3</sub>K<sub>3</sub>O<sub>1.5</sub>(OH)<sub>3</sub>(HCOO)<sub>3</sub>(CB6)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>(DMF)<sub>3</sub>]·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of KNO3 (20 mg, 0.20 mmol), DMF (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 3, mixed with an amorphous material which was not further characterized, appeared in low yield within three days.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Cs<sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>3</sub>(CB6)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>][(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Cs<sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>3</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(CB6)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>][(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]·2NO<sub>3</sub>·10H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of CsNO3 (40 mg, 0.21 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 4 appeared in low yield within one month.

[UO<sub>2</sub>Na<sub>3</sub>(Htir)(CB6)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>11</sub>][UO<sub>2</sub>(Htir)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·NO<sub>3</sub>·11H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of Na2H2tir (31 mg, 0.10 mmol) and of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol) were dissolved in demineralized water (1.5 mL). Orange crystals of complex 5 appeared in low yield upon slow evaporation of the solution at room temperature over a period of one month.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Na<sub>2</sub>(Htir)<sub>2</sub>(CB6)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>]·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>6</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of Na2H2tir (31 mg, 0.10 mmol) and of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Orange crystals of complex 6 appeared in low yield overnight. Heating for longer periods did not improve the yield significantly.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>K<sub>2</sub>(Htir)<sub>2</sub>(CB6)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>]·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>7</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of Na2H2tir (31 mg, 0.10 mmol), and of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 50-fold excess of KNO3 (50 mg, 0.50 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Orange crystals of complex 7 appeared overnight.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O, NaNO3, and KNO3 were purchased from Prolabo, CsNO3 from Acros, and cucurbit[6]uril pentahydrate and the disodium salt of Tiron from Fluka.

[Na3(CB6)(H2O)8][(UO2)2(OH)2(NO3)4]⋅NO3⋅2H2O (1)

CB6⋅5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of NaNO3 (17 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared in low yield within three days.

[Na1.5(CB6)(H2O)4][(UO2)6O2(OH)6(HCOO)3.5(H2O)]⋅8H2O (2)

CB6⋅5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of NaNO3 (17 mg, 0.20 mmol), DMF (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (3 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 2 appeared in low yield within two days.

[(UO2)3K3O1.5(OH)3(HCOO)3(CB6)3(H2O)6(DMF)3]⋅3H2O (3)

CB6⋅5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of KNO3 (20 mg, 0.20 mmol), DMF (0.5 mL), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 3, mixed with an amorphous material which was not further characterized, appeared in low yield within three days.

[(UO2)2Cs2(OH)3(CB6)(H2O)4][(UO2)2Cs2(OH)3(NO3)2(CB6)(H2O)2][(UO2)2(OH)2(NO3)4]⋅2NO3⋅10H2O (4)

CB6⋅5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of CsNO3 (40 mg, 0.21 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 4 appeared in low yield within one month.

[UO2Na3(Htir)(CB6)(H2O)11][UO2(Htir)(H2O)3]⋅NO3⋅11H2O (5)

CB6⋅5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of Na2H2tir (31 mg, 0.10 mmol) and of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol) were dissolved in demineralized water (1.5 mL). Orange crystals of complex 5 appeared in low yield upon slow evaporation of the solution at room temperature over a period of one month.

[(UO2)2Na2(Htir)2(CB6)(H2O)8]⋅4H2O (6)

CB6⋅5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of Na2H2tir (31 mg, 0.10 mmol) and of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Orange crystals of complex 6 appeared in low yield overnight. Heating for longer periods did not improve the yield significantly.

[(UO2)2K2(Htir)2(CB6)(H2O)8]⋅4H2O (7)

CB6⋅5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of Na2H2tir (31 mg, 0.10 mmol), and of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 50-fold excess of KNO3 (50 mg, 0.50 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Orange crystals of complex 7 appeared overnight.
